curriculumTitle: PinStack STEM: Physics & Physiology in Action
overview: A rigorous, federal grant-compliant STEM curriculum designed for Upward Bound (UB) and UB Math & Science (UBMS) programs. This field curriculum utilizes the controlled environments of PinStack facilities (Bowling Lanes, Laser Tag Arena, High Ropes Course) as active physics and biology laboratories. The curriculum is structured to justify costs under 2 CFR 200 by transforming recreational equipment into scientific apparatus for measuring momentum, friction, infrared signal processing, and physiological stress responses. It aligns directly with Texas TEKS and federal objectives to improve standardized test performance in Math and Science.
prerequisites: Completion of Algebra I (linear equations); Introduction to Biology recommended.
totalDurationEstimate: 5.5 Hours (1 hour classroom prep, 3.5 hours on-site, 1 hour post-trip analysis)

fieldTrips.name: PinStack (Las Colinas or Plano)

fieldTrips.description: A multi-venue facility containing regulation bowling lanes, a two-level laser tag arena, and a high ropes course suspended above the arcade.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: The facility provides long-distance tracks for friction coefficients (bowling), controlled infrared environments (laser tag), and vertical structures for triangulation (ropes), which cannot be replicated in a standard classroom.

activities.title: Rolling with Physics: Momentum & Friction on the Lanes
activities.description: Students transform bowling lanes into Newtonian physics labs. They calculate average velocity, estimate the coefficient of kinetic friction based on oil pattern deceleration, and calculate momentum transfers (impulse) during pin impact.
learningObjectives: Calculate average velocity using distance/time intervals.
Analyze conservation of momentum (p=mv) during ball-pin collisions.
Differentiate between static and kinetic friction on oiled surfaces.
Calculate Kinetic Energy (KE = 1/2mv^2) of the projectile.
teks: Physics 4(A): Calculate the effect of forces on objects, including the law of inertia and the relationship between force, mass, and acceleration.
Physics 6(C): Calculate the mechanical energy of, power generated within, impulse applied to, and momentum of a physical system.
Physics 4(D): Calculate the effect of forces on objects, including friction.
texasStemStandards: STEM 1(A): Apply the engineering design process to identify and solve problems.
STEM 4(B): Use critical thinking and problem solving to make informed decisions.

materialsList.item: Stopwatches or Phones with precision timers

brief: Book lanes in advance; request 'house lights' (no cosmic bowl) for visibility.
Group students by 4: Bowler, Timer, Recorder, Spotter.
Ensure safety regarding the foul line (oil).
detailed: Contact PinStack Events to secure the 'Educational/Non-Profit' rate.
Pre-Trip: Review the formula for Momentum (p=mv) and Kinetic Energy (KE=0.5mv^2).
On-site: Instruct students to weigh their chosen house balls using the digital scale to convert lbs to kg.
Monitor students to ensure they are recording data, not just playing. The 'Bowler' must aim for consistency, not high scores.

brief: Time the ball from foul line to head pin.
detailed: Select two balls of different masses. Record the mass in kg.
Timer: Start timing exactly when the ball crosses the foul line. Stop when it hits the pins.
Distance: Use 18.29 meters (standard lane length).
Calculate Velocity (v = 18.29 / time).
Calculate Momentum (p = mass * velocity) for both heavy and light balls.
Compare: Which ball had higher momentum? Which had higher velocity?

activities.title: The Physiology of Adrenaline: Laser Tag Biometrics
activities.description: Students wear heart rate monitors during Laser Tag sessions to analyze the physiological effects of acute stress (fight or flight). They also explore the physics of infrared light transmission and receiver technology.
learningObjectives: Measure and graph heart rate recovery times.
Explain the sympathetic nervous system response ('fight or flight').
Understand Infrared (IR) light properties on the Electromagnetic Spectrum.
teks: Biology 10(A): Describe interactions among systems performing regulation and defense.
Physics 7(C): Compare characteristics of electromagnetic waves (Infrared).
texasStemStandards: STEM 3(A): Research and analyze STEM careers (Biomedical Engineering).

materialsList.item: Wrist-based Heart Rate Monitors (or student smartwatches)

brief: Establish Resting Heart Rate (RHR) before entry.
Ensure students know how to find a pulse if no monitors are available.
detailed: Explain that Laser Tag 'guns' are actually Infrared Emitters (like a TV remote), not actual lasers.
Have students record RHR while seated in the briefing room.
Instruct students to check their pulse/watch immediately upon the end-of-game buzzer.
Conduct a cool-down session where students record HR every 60 seconds for 5 minutes to graph the 'Recovery Curve'.
In the briefing room, sit still and measure your beats per minute (BPM). This is your Baseline.
During the game, move safely but actively.
Immediately after the game, record your Peak HR.
Sit down outside. Record your HR at 1 min, 2 min, 3 min, 4 min, and 5 min post-game.
Later, you will graph this data to see how fast your heart returns to homeostasis.

activities.title: Vertical Engineering: Ropes Course Trigonometry
activities.description: Students use the High Ropes Course to study mechanical advantage (pulleys) and use trigonometry (clinometers) to calculate the height of obstacles without direct measurement.
learningObjectives: Calculate height using clinometers and tangent ratios.
Analyze mechanical advantage in pulley/belay systems.
teks: Geometry 9(A): Determine lengths/angles in a right triangle using sine, cosine, tangent.
Physics 6(B): Investigate kinetic and potential energy transformations.
texasStemStandards: STEM 2(B): Use engineering graphics and technical writing to communicate ideas.

detailed: Ensure all students have signed waivers for the ropes course.
Pre-Activity: Teach the usage of a clinometer to find the angle of elevation.
Designate a specific vertical beam or platform on the course as the 'Target'.
Discuss the belay system: Point out the pulley. Ask students if it is fixed or movable (mechanical advantage).

brief: Sight top of course to get angle.
detailed: Stand at a distance from the ropes course where you can see the top platform.
Measure the distance (Adjacent side) from your feet to the base of the structure.
Use the clinometer to find the Angle of Elevation to the top platform.
Measure the distance from your eye to the ground (Eye Height).
Formula: Height = (Distance * Tan(Angle)) + Eye Height.
While on the course, observe the trusses. How do triangles provide stability?
